name: Swift Parrot
description: It is a relatively small parrot with predominantly bright green coloration. The crown and face are bluish, the forehead and throat red. It has long, narrow wings and a pointed tail. Adult males have red under-tail and wing coverts, visible in flight.
spread_note: The swift parrot is one of the few migratory parrot species. It breeds in Tasmania and spends the rest of the year in southeastern Australia.
food_note: Pollen and nectar of eucalypts, insects, fruits, seeds
proportions: Length 25 cm; wingspan 32–36 cm; weight 50–74 g
attractions: The swift parrot is related to rosellas but resembles lorikeets in its feeding habits. It is closely tied to eucalypts, nesting in their hollows and feeding on them. Considered the fastest flier among parrots, its swift, swallow-like flight earned it its name. A male trying to attract a female or intimidate a rival spreads its wings to reveal their red undersides.
projects_note: It is listed as an endangered species on the IUCN Red List. Estimates suggest only about 1,000 pairs survive, with the main threat being the loss of suitable nesting trees.
breeding: We have kept swift parrots since 2012.
